facts.fact: It is the home of the Little Salmon/Carmacks First Nation, a Northern Tutchone-speaking people.
Its population was 1577 as of the 2021 census, making it the second-largest municipality in Yukon.
It is inseparably linked to the Klondike Gold Rush (1896–1899).
Haines Junction lies east of Kluane National Park and Reserve.
It is at Kilometre 1632 (historical mile 1016) of the Alaska Highway at its junction with the Haines Highway, hence the name of the community.
According to the 2021 census, the population was 688.
However, the Yukon Bureau of Statistics lists the population count for 2022 as 1018.
It is also the home of the First Nation of Na-Cho Nyak Dun, whose people primarily speak the northern variety of the Tutchone language.
The village was named after former circus acrobat turned settler and explorer Alfred Mayo.
Its only school is the J V Clark School, which is named after James Vincent Clark (1924–1994).
Na-Cho Nyäk Dun translates into "big river people." The community, formerly called Mayo Landing, is serviced by Mayo Airport.
It had a population of 200 in 2016.
The Yukon Bureau of Statistics estimated a population of 496 in 2019.
As of December 2022 the school had 46 students with 34 in primary and 12 in secondary grades.
As of the 2023 - 2024 school year the principal is Douglas Cooper.
Tourist attractions in Watson Lake include the Northern Lights Centre and the much-imitated original Sign Post Forest.
Watson Lake and the neighbouring Upper Liard settlement are the home of the Liard River First Nation, a member of the Kaska Dena Council.
The town is named for Frank Watson, an American-born trapper and prospector, who settled in the area at the end of the 19th century.
Watson Lake is near the Liard River, at the junction of the Robert Campbell Highway and the Alaska Highway.
The Sign Post Forest is one of four roadside attractions featured on the first series of the Canadian Roadside Attractions Series issued by Canada Post on July 6, 2009.
The Stewart–Cassiar Highway's northern end is 22 km (14 mi) west of Watson Lake.

The town is also served by the Watson Lake Airport; the airport was formerly served by Canadian Pacific Air Lines and other local and regional airlines, but now by Air North and corporate and charter services.
It had a population of 1133 in 2021.
The Sign Post Forest was started in 1942 by a homesick United States Army Corps of Engineers G I working on the Alaska Highway, who put up a sign with the name of his home town and the distance.
Others followed suit and the tradition continues to this day.
Whitehorse is the capital of Yukon, and the largest city in Northern Canada.
It was incorporated in 1950 and is located at kilometre 1426 (Historic Mile 918) on the Alaska Highway in southern Yukon.
The city was named after the White Horse Rapids for their resemblance to the mane of a white horse.
Whitehorse's downtown and Riverdale areas occupy both shores of the Yukon River, which rises in British Columbia and meets the Bering Sea in Alaska.
Because of the city's location in the Whitehorse valley and relative proximity to the Pacific Ocean, the climate tends to be milder.
As of the 2021 Canadian census, the population was 28201 within city boundaries and 31913 in the census agglomeration.
These figures represent approximately 70 and 79 percent, respectively, of the total population of Yukon.
